ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometric thresholds demonstrate varying degrees of sensorineural loss greater than 55 dB HL above 1000 Hz.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cochlear dead regions (ruled out as barrier)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Significant improvement in WRS with high-frequency gain suggests functional neural elements despite severity of loss, arguing against dead regions preventing amplification benefit.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To establish hearing thresholds and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess baseline word recognition and compare with performance using additional high-frequency gain.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Evaluation of four patients with high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss revealed that adding 14 dB of gain above 1000 Hz significantly improved word recognition scores (25-40% improvement) compared to baseline. This indicates that despite potential cochlear dead regions or severe loss, patients can utilize high-frequency cues when made audible.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Four cases (A-D) showed high-frequency SNHL > 55 dB HL above 1000 Hz; Case D showed severe loss with PTA of 88 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Significant improvement with 14 dB HF gain vs baseline. Case A: 50% to 80%; Case B: 75% to 100%; Case C: 65% to 95%; Case D: 20% to 60%.

proposed_items: Hearing aid fitting with verification of sufficient high-frequency gain
Use of high-frequency gain-adjusted word recognition testing to predict amplification benefit
counseling_actions: Explain that despite high-frequency hearing loss, the auditory nerves can still process speech when it is made audible
Highlight the significant improvement in word recognition (25-40%) achieved with high-frequency amplification
Counsel that 'dead regions' do not necessarily prevent benefit from hearing aids
Set realistic expectations for improved speech clarity with appropriately fitted devices

escalation.rationale_short: Proceed with hearing aid fitting and management based on demonstrated potential for benefit.

follow_up_plan.objective: Fit amplification and verify high-frequency audibility to maximize speech understanding.

expected_outcome: Significant improvements in Word Recognition Scores (WRSs) were observed in all cases where baseline WRSs were 80% or poorer.
The results support using high-frequency gain-adjusted testing as a diagnostic tool for counseling and predicting potential benefit from amplification.
